Hi Jeff, 

I guess such bloat is inevitable in case of fitness plateau bein=
g reached. One suggestion is to try pruning the networks with the addition =
of subtractive mutations (remove link & remove node). Or better try phased =
searching, complexification followed by simplification stages. This will im=
prove things for sure. 

Peter

--- In neat@yahoogroups.com, Jeff Clune <jc=
lune@...> wrote:
>
> Hello all-
> 
> I have been noticing in many of my Hyp=
erNEAT runs recently that the number
> of CPPN nodes is shooting up as a st=
eep linear function of time
> (generations), and is relatively unaffected b=
y the fitness trajectory of the
> run. 
> 
> See here, for example
> 
> htt=
ps://www.msu.edu/~jclune/delme/CPPN-Node-Bloat-1.png
> 
> Sometimes it gets=
 really pathological, with almost 25 CPPN nodes being added
> every 100 gen=
erations, such as here:
> 
> https://www.msu.edu/~jclune/delme/CPPN-Node-Bl=
oat-2.png
> 
> Oddly, and interestingly, the runs in this second figure whe=
re the CPPN node
> count linearly increases are in a changing environment a=
nd those runs where
> the CPPN node count flatlines (at a healthy level) ar=
e in a constant
> environment.
> 
> Are any of you seeing such bloat?
> 
> =
One problem is that it makes the runs slow to a crawl, because running
> po=
pulations with 200-node genomes is really slow. Moreover, I doubt
> evoluti=
on can make too much progress with that many nodes (although I have
> seen =
fitness continue to increase even with such large genomes).
> 
> I have tri=
ed dropping the MutateAddNodeProbability from 0.03 to 0.003 and
> that defi=
nitely changes the slope of the line, but it still linearly
> increases. Th=
e good news is that it does not affect fitness to much.
> 
> Any thoughts? =

> 
> 
> Kind regards,
> Jeff Clune
> 
> Digital Evolution Lab, Michigan St=
ate University
> jclune@...
> www.msu.edu/~jclune
>
